Introduction

Vasculitis is characterized by inflammation of blood vessels, leading to end-organ ischemia and dysfunction.  There are ~15 distinct vasculitides, which are categorized by the size of vessels involved (large, medium, small, or variable).

General pathophysiology

Despite diverse presentations, all vasculitides feature systemic inflammation and organ dysfunction.

Systemic inflammation

Patients typically have constitutional symptoms (eg, fever, malaise, anorexia, nonspecific myalgias) and markedly elevated acute phase markers (eg, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein).

Organ dysfunction

Organ injury in vasculitis is primarily due to ischemia.  In large vessel vasculitis (eg, giant cell arteritis), major arteries are narrowed from infiltration and inflammatory damage to the vessel wall.  Medium vessel vasculitis (eg, Kawasaki disease) can also induce aneurysm formation due to compromised elastic integrity; these can rupture or thrombose, also leading to ischemia.  Small vessel vasculitis (eg, granulomatosis with polyangiitis) causes microcirculatory ischemia as well as capillary extravasation (eg, glomerulonephritis, alveolar hemorrhage, cutaneous purpura).

Vasculitis severity can be graded using organ system-based scoring tools.  Organ-threatening vasculitis refers to involvement that leads to permanent loss of function if not urgently treated (eg, acute renal failure, skin necrosis, optic ischemia).

Large vessel vasculitides

Large vessel vasculitides affect the aorta and its major branches (eg, subclavian and carotid arteries).

Takayasu arteritis

Takayasu arteritis (

) mainly affects young women (age <40) of Asian descent.  It is an idiopathic vasculitis featuring transmural granulomatous inflammation, eventually leading to narrowing and stenosis (
image 1
).  Specific manifestations include aorto-occlusive findings (eg, claudication, ischemic ulcers) in the extremities, bruits, and brachial pulse pressure deficits.  Major complications include aortic regurgitation, limb infarction, and ischemic stroke.  Treatment includes immunosuppression (eg, glucocorticoids, biologic monoclonal antibodies) and stenting of critically stenotic arteries.

Giant cell arteritis

Giant cell arteritis (GCA) (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
) mainly affects older women (age >50).  It is an idiopathic vasculitis with transmural granulomatous inflammation of the arterial wall (
image 2
).  It is strongly associated with polymyalgia rheumatica (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).  The temporal artery is most commonly involved (ie, temporal arteritis), resulting in headache and scalp tenderness.  Jaw claudication and tongue pain (maxillary and lingual arteries) are common.  The feared complication of GCA is ophthalmic artery involvement, which initially presents with amaurosis fugax ("fleeting darkness").  Without urgent treatment (eg, empiric high-dose glucocorticoids started prior to temporal artery biopsy), it can rapidly progress to optic disc infarction and permanent blindness.

Other aortitis

Other causes of aortitis, sometimes affecting main offshoots as well, include tertiary syphilis and some autoinflammatory conditions (eg, ankylosing spondylitis).  Complications include aneurysm formation, rupture, spontaneous aortic dissection, and aortic regurgitation.

Medium vessel vasculitides

Medium vessel vasculitides affect peripheral arteries (eg, renal, mesenteric, coronary, popliteal). 

Polyarteritis nodosa

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
) mainly affects young adults with chronic hepatitis B and C infection.  It is an immune complexâ€“mediated vasculitis that causes nongranulomatous inflammation and fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall (
image 3
), leading to microaneurysms and narrowing resembling beads on a string (
figure 1
).  The microaneurysms are prone to rupture, and narrowing causes end-organ ischemia.  PAN can affect most organs, including the kidneys (eg, hypertension, renal infarction), bowel (eg, mesenteric ischemia), and nervous system (eg, mononeuritis multiplex).  Management involves immunosuppression (eg, prednisone, cyclophosphamide) and treatment of underlying viral hepatitis.

Kawasaki disease

Kawasaki disease (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
) mainly affects toddlers (age <5) of Asian descent.  It is thought to represent massive T-cell activation triggered by recent infection (eg, bacterial otitis, viral respiratory).  Clinically, the syndrome resembles a superantigen-like response (eg, cytokine storm) with high fever, mucositis (eg, strawberry tongue, oral fissures, conjunctivitis), exfoliation, and cervical lymphadenopathy.  The most serious complication is coronary artery aneurysm formation, which can lead to myocardial infarction, coronary rupture (eg, hemopericardium), or sudden cardiac death (eg, arrhythmia).  The aneurysms can be detected by echocardiography (recommended for all patients).  Treatment involves intravenous immunoglobulin and high-dose aspirin (benefits outweigh risk of Reye syndrome).

Buerger disease (thromboangiitis obliterans)

Thromboangiitis obliterans (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 6
) mainly affects young male smokers.  The inflammatory response is relatively limited to the endothelial lining (ie, sparing the arterial media and adventitia).  Endothelial dysfunction and upregulated leukocyte adhesion molecules (eg, VCAM-1) induce a prothrombotic state.  Angiography shows segmental blockages, vessel pruning, and tortuous wispy collaterals (eg, corkscrew appearance).  Signs of arterial ischemia include Raynaud phenomenon, digital ulcerations (
image 4
), and gangrene.  Treatment involves smoking cessation (most important and effective), antiplatelet therapy, and arterial vasodilators (eg, prostaglandin). 

Small vessel vasculitides

Small vessel vasculitides affect arterioles, capillaries beds (eg, alveoli, glomeruli), and venules.  They are classified into antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA)â€“associated and immune complexÂ­â€“mediated vasculitis.

ANCA-associated

There are 3 ANCA-associated vasculitides (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 7
): granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), and microscopic polyangiitis (MPA).  The ANCAs activate deganulated neutrophils within capillaries, resulting in inflammation and fibrinoid necrosis.  All 3 conditions can cause rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis with copious inflammatory cells and fibrinous material in Bowman space (ie, crescentic) but with characteristic absence of immunoglobulin and complement deposition (ie, pauci-immune).

  • GPA (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 8
    ):  Most closely linked with anti-proteinase-3 (PR3), located in neutrophil cytoplasmic granules (ie, c-ANCA).  Manifestations include necrotizing ulceration of the upper respiratory tract (eg, erosive sinusitis, epistaxis), lung tissue necrosis (eg, cavitary lesions) and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, and glomerulonephritis.  Vessel histopathology shows neutrophilic inflammation with granulomas.
  • EGPA (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 9
    ):  More closely linked with anti-myeloperoxidase (MPO), located in neutrophil perinuclear granules (eg, p-ANCA).  Manifestations include a prodromal phase of asthma (often refractory), allergic sinus disease (eg, nasal polyps), and eosinophilic organ infiltration (eg, pulmonary opacities).  Later, the vasculitic phase causes glomerulonephritis, myocarditis, and neurologic involvement.  Vessel histopathology shows eosinophilic inflammation with granulomas.
  • MPA:  More closely linked with anti-MPO.  Its clinical picture is very similar to GPA, with prominent glomerulonephritis (main manifestation) and alveolar inflammation.  However, vessel histopathology shows neutrophilic inflammation without granulomas.

Treatment involves an induction phase of immunosuppression (typically with high-dose glucocorticoids and cyclophosphamide) to control inflammation, followed by a maintenance phase (typically with rituximab [anti-B-cell monoclonal]) to reduce autoantibody formation.

Immune complex-mediated

There are 3 major immune complex-mediated vasculitides: cryoglobulinemic vasculitis, IgA vasculitis, and anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease.  Because complement activation is a major element of vessel injury, all conditions share the findings of serum hypocomplementemia with positive tissue complement staining.

  • Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 10
    ):  Seen in mixed cryoglobulinemia, primarily associated with chronic viral infections (especially hepatitis C virus).  Circulating immune complexes (consisting of rheumatoid factor [IgM] bound to viral proteins) deposit in capillaries and venules.  Manifestations include palpable purpura and skin ulcers, glomerulonephritis, and polyneuropathy. 
  • IgA vasculitis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 11
    ) (ie, Henoch-SchÃ¶nlein purpura):  Mainly affects preschool children and is potentially triggered by upper respiratory infection.  Circulating immune complexes (IgA bound to viral or self proteins) deposit in capillaries and venules.  Manifestations include palpable purpura, arthritis, abdominal distress (eg, hematochezia, intussusception), and glomerulonephritis. 
  • Anti-GBM disease (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 12
    ) (ie, Goodpasture syndrome):  Autoantibodies targeting type IV collagen (most abundant in the basal lamina) leading to formation of immune complexes (IgG bound to collagen IV epitopes) in situ.  Manifestations include glomerulonephritis and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage.

Treatment of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis and anti-GBM disease involves plasmapheresis (to remove immune complexes) and adjunctive immunosuppression.  IgA vasculitis generally resolves with supportive care (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), and immunosuppression is rarely needed.

Other

There is a group of vasculitis called cutaneous small vessel vasculitis, which includes:

  • Drug-induced ANCA (levamisole, cocaine)
  • Drug-induced immune complex (hypersensitivity) vasculitis (eg, allopurinoletc.)
  • Urticarial (idiopathic [anti-C1q], secondary) vasculitis

These are primarily skin-limited but sometimes have systemic manifestations.

Variable vessel

BehÃ§et disease

BehÃ§et disease (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 13
) mainly affects young males of Turkish and Middle Eastern descent (eg, associated with HLA-B51 haplotype).  It involves nonspecific mixed inflammation of multiple vessels.  The main manifestation is sterile pyogenic lesions of the skin and mucous membranes (eg, painful, recurrent genital and oral aphthous ulcers).  A positive pathergy reaction (ie, large pustular skin lesion out of proportion to small needle prick) is a distinctive feature.  Severe complications include pulmonary artery aneurysms and deep venous thrombosis.  Treatment includes topical corticosteroids and colchicine (blocks neutrophils) for mucocutaneous ulcers, or systemic immunosuppression (eg, TNF-É‘ inhibitor) for organ-threatening disease.

Cogan syndrome

Cogan syndrome is a rare panvasculitis that preferentially affects the eye and inner ear.  Ocular involvement includes episcleritis and keratitis, leading to corneal scarring.  Vestibular involvement resembles MÃ©niÃ¨re disease (eg, attacks of vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss).  Large (eg, aortitis) and medium vessel (eg, renal artery stenosis) components can be present concurrently.

Nonvasculitic differential diagnosis

Because vasculitides can affect any organ, the differential is vast.  Important mimickers are described below.

Large vessel

  • Atherosclerosis can induce arterial stenoses, bruits, and ischemia of the extremities and eye (eg, atheroembolic central retinal artery occlusion) and aortic aneurysms or dissection.  However, atheromas typically show calcification (vs transmural edema in vasculitis), and systemic inflammatory symptoms are typically absent.
  • Genetic connective tissue disorders (eg, Marfan, Ehlers-Danlos) can produce aortic aneurysms, spontaneous dissections, and sudden monocular vision loss (eg, retinal detachment).  However, skin hyperlaxity or joint hypermobility is present, and systemic inflammation is absent.

Medium vessel

  • Group A streptococcal complications such as scarlet fever and Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome can resemble Kawasaki disease.  Both are associated with prolonged fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, exfoliative erythroderma, and mucositis (eg, strawberry tongue).  However, pharyngitis is usually present, and coronary artery aneurysms are not seen.
  • Fibromuscular dysplasia is an idiopathic disorder of myofibroblast proliferation in the arterial media, leading to segmental dilation and structures (string of beads, similar to PAN).  Renal artery stenosis (eg, severe hypertension) and mesenteric ischemia can be seen.  However, underlying etiologies (eg, chronic HBV infection) and systemic inflammatory symptoms are absent.

Small vessel

  • Relapsing polychondritis involves autoinflammatory cartilage destruction.  It mimics GPA, with systemic symptoms and necrotic ulceration of upper airway cartilage (eg, nasal septum, trachea).  However, auricular and joint involvement is usually prominent, whereas renal and alveolar involvement are not.  The inflammation is primarily lymphocytic rather than neutrophilic or granulomatous.
  • Immune complex glomerulonephritis (eg, poststreptococcal, endocarditis-associated, IgA nephropathy, lupus nephritis) closely overlaps with small vessel vasculitis.  The clinical picture is often ambiguous.  For example, pulmonary cavitary lesions and glomerulonephritis could represent either GPA or right-sided endocarditis; diffuse alveolar hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis could represent either systemic lupus erythematosus-related antiphospholipid syndrome or anti-GBM disease.  Renal biopsy is almost always indicated for clarification.

Summary

Vasculitis involves inflammation of blood vessels leading to organ ischemia and dysfunction.  It is classified by the size of the affected vessels:

  • The large vessel vasculitides involve transmural granulomatous inflammation of the aorta and its major branches.  Organ-threatening complications include stroke or aortic regurgitation (Takayasu arteritis) and blindness (giant cell arteritis).
  • Medium vessel vasculitides involve nongranulomatous inflammation of peripheral arteries.  They tend to cause alternating strictures and microaneurysms.  Organ-threatening complications include mesenteric ischemia (polyarteritis nodosa) and coronary artery aneurysms (Kawasaki disease).
  • Small vessel vasculitides involve antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodyâ€“mediated (eg, granulomatosis with polyangiitis) or complement-mediated (eg, cryoglobulinemic vasculitis) inflammation of capillaries and venules.  They are known for causing pulmonary-renal syndrome (glomerulonephritis and alveolar hemorrhage).
